dietary_recommendations: Within the first hour of arrival, drink 500 mL of isotonic fluid, then repeat 200 mL every 30 minutes for the next two hours.
supplements: Take a 10 mg/kg caffeine dose during the trip.
workouts: Take brief 5‑minute standing or torso‑stretch breaks every 45 minutes.
trackers: Use actigraphy to guide adjustments of light exposure and sleep schedule if fatigue persists.
lifestyle_recommendations: Apply the hydration and micro‑break protocol consistently on each leg of your trip.

dietary_recommendations: Drink 500 ml of water 4–6 h before takeoff, plus the sea salt and potassium.
Add 30 g of complex carbohydrates (oatmeal or rice).
Within 30 min of landing, break the fast with a balanced snack that includes protein, carbohydrate, and fat.
Eat protein+carb at the new breakfast and lunch according to the new time zone.
lifestyle_recommendations: Align macro windows to the new time zone (protein+carb at breakfast and lunch).
Keep a small carb snack before bed to reset the circadian rhythm.
Phase‑advance light exposure: 30–60 min of full‑spectrum light (≥10 000 lux) between 6–8 am local time upon arrival
Avoid blue light 2–3 h before bedtime; use blue‑blocking glasses if needed
Gradually shift bedtime earlier by 1–2 h each day
Enforce a strict no‑caffeine policy after 2200 h
Implement a 10‑minute pre‑sleep wind‑down routine in dim light
Do not use overnight melatonin during the circadian shift
Incorporate >10,000 lux dawn‑simulated light exposure for the first 30 minutes after arrival.
Block blue light more than 2 hours before target bedtime using amber filters or blue‑blocking glasses.
Avoid caffeine after 13:00; take a single 100‑mg dose 4 hours before the new bedtime to enhance sleep onset.
supplements: Take a 100‑mg caffeine dose 4 hours before bedtime.
dietary_recommendations: Have a low‑glycogenic snack at 17:00 to reinforce circadian cue for earlier sleep.
Shift protein intake to the first half of the day.
supplements: Take 200 mg of L‑carnitine (or 5‑HTP) at 8 pm.
Take 400 mg of melatonin 30 minutes before a 10 pm bedtime.
lifestyle_recommendations: Keep caffeine strictly within the first 4 hours after awakening (≤10 am).
Limit post‑6 pm light exposure and use a blue‑blocking lamp if needed.

dietary_recommendations: Split the protein shake into two 10‑g servings
Replace the protein shake with a low‑glycemic carbohydrate snack
lifestyle_recommendations: Delay caffeine consumption by 30–60 minutes after the protein shake

dietary_recommendations: Split 20 g of protein into two 10 g servings: 10 g at 8:45 am and the second 10 g at 9:15 am.
Take 30 mg caffeine immediately after the first 10 g of protein; if avoiding caffeine, replace it with 15 g of low‑GI oats at 8:45 am.
Maintain this split to preserve >85 % of baseline HRV while providing alertness.
lifestyle_recommendations: Space the protein servings 30 minutes apart to keep sympathetic tone lower and preserve HRV.
supplements: 30 mg caffeine (if caffeine is not avoided).
Timed low‑dose melatonin (0.5‑1 mg) taken 30–45 min before bedtime
lifestyle_recommendations: 30‑min guided progressive muscle relaxation or controlled breathing right before sleep
Avoid blue‑light exposure for 1–2 h before bed (use a blue‑light filter or night mode), then dim lights to cue melatonin production
trackers: Set the wearable’s 'sleep‑ready' reminder to trigger when HRV, skin‑temperature, and ambient light data indicate bedtime readiness

supplements: Take melatonin nightly between 10 pm and 11 pm, ensuring at least a two‑hour buffer after your 8 pm beta‑blocker dose to mitigate additive hypotension.
If you notice an exaggerated nocturnal blood‑pressure dip (large drop in HRV or shallow skin‑temperature rise within the first hour after the beta‑blocker), consider adjusting the melatonin dose.
trackers: Use a watch that monitors heart‑rate variability (HRV) and skin temperature to detect a large drop in HRV or a shallow rise in skin temperature during the first hour after taking the beta‑blocker.
Monitor HRV and cuff‑based nighttime SBP next night to confirm the change
Track that pattern nightly; most wearables can flag ≥20 mmHg systolic loss plus the HRV/temperature thresholds above, but confirm with a 24‑h ABPM for reliability.
medicines: Adjust your beta‑blocker dose or timing.

trackers: Keep the wearable device on from 9 pm to 6 am to monitor systolic BP, low‑frequency HRV component, and skin temperature for nocturnal hypotension detection.

medicines: Pair a high‑dose beta‑blocker with melatonin to blunt sympathetic tone
Adjust the beta‑blocker dose if nighttime skin temperature >33 °C and RMSSD <20 ms are observed on 24‑hour ambulatory blood‑pressure monitoring
trackers: Perform a 24‑hour ambulatory blood‑pressure monitor before changing therapy
Use wearables for trend detection; flag any BP trough <90 mmHg systolic or >20 mmHg drop from daytime mean, and flag HRV values <20 ms as a red flag
Flag SDNN or RMSSD < 20 ms, or HRV ratio > 0.75 as a red‑line for nocturnal hypotension risk.
Monitor skin temperature: keep it above 31 °C (87.8 °F) throughout the night.
lifestyle_recommendations: Stay on schedule and monitor those thresholds; if limits are crossed, adjust the plan.

trackers: Use a wearable to continuously log HRV and skin temperature during the 9 am test—no reset is needed for uninterrupted data.
Monitor nocturnal hypotension thresholds: SDNN ≤ 20 ms or RMSSD ≤ 10 ms; flag a temperature drop if skin temperature falls by ≥ 1 °C below baseline or goes below 31 °C.
No action is required if these thresholds are not breached; the device will auto‑alert only when both criteria are met.
Review baseline measures in the app and confirm alert threshold settings before the test.
Set alert triggers: when SDNN ≤ 15 ms or RMSSD ≤ 8 ms.
Use the past 7 nights to establish a personalized HRV baseline.
lifestyle_recommendations: Maintain skin temperature above 31 °C during monitoring periods.

trackers: Set a brief 30‑minute custom baseline during the flight by toggling the "time‑zone override" option in the tracker app.
Increase recovery target by 20% for the next 48 hours.
lifestyle_recommendations: Implement a heavier nightly wind‑down routine.

trackers: Monitor the wearable data stream throughout the flight
lifestyle_recommendations: Apply a ±10 % buffer to the HRV alert threshold during jet‑lag transitions
